results.title: Imperial Guard Costume from The Last Emperor
results.brief_description:
From seller: An Imperial Guard uniform from the 1987 multi-Oscar winning historical drama The Last Emperor. This elaborate outfit first appeared when a young Pu Yi (Richard Vuu), aged a mere three years old, is taken at night from his mother with only his wet nurse for comfort, and escorted to the secretive Forbidden City to become Emperor, and later at his coronation.
The ensemble has multiple layers and would have been a challenge to wear atop a horse during the lengthy hours on set. The imposing uniform consists of a pair of navy rayon trousers, undertunic and skirt, topped with a jacket and three-piece skirt decorated with an Indian print gold metallic mesh trimmed in black satin and adorned with brass pauldrons and metal roundels. In addition to the already comprehensive costume is the traditional metal helmet trimmed with stamp pressed brass reliefs, topped by a rabbit fur and horse hair plume worn over a protective balaclava hood. Completing the costume is a leather belt sash with hard rubber sword and tsuba.
This is a unique opportunity to acquire an instantly recognisable costume from the first scenes of the young Emperor’s life, and although has some slight distress due to use on set and age it is still in very good condition.
This comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-05. Sound and Colour → MI-05-C01

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.

results.title: 16mm news camera with Cosmicar zoom lens used by GTV-9
results.brief_description: Model 0. Manufactured by Mitchell Camera Corporation Glendale, California. Complete with added Cosmicar zoom lens 22.5-90mm and wooden tripod. Used by GTV 9.

constellations_primary.name: Princesses, rom-coms and sit-coms
constellations_primary.description: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field, but they were also used by film production companies and on TV shows, with some of those involved going on to define different genres.

results.title_for_label: 16mm news camera with Cosmicar zoom lens used by GTV-9
results.description: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field. Three-legged tripods made from firm materials like steel and wood helped steady the kind of image that was collected in production vans for Cinesound Productions and Movietone News. Designed and manufactured in Los Angeles, this model was an improved design on the earlier Mitchell cameras, which were widely used by film production companies like those at Pagewood Studios in Sydney, Australia. The Mitchell Newsreel Camera was a quieter alternative, making it less invasive on sets and in the field.
description_for_label: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field. Three-legged tripods made from firm materials like steel and wood helped steady the kind of image that was collected in production vans for Cinesound Productions and Movietone News. Designed and manufactured in Los Angeles, this model was an improved design on the earlier Mitchell cameras, which were widely used by film production companies like those at Pagewood Studios in Sydney, Australia. The Mitchell Newsreel Camera was a quieter alternative, making it less invasive on sets and in the field.
